Quoting Michael Feathers <mfeathers@...>:
>> I suspect that it's=
 the
>> same reason most developers worry about performance more than good
=
>> design: it's easier to quantify.
>>
> I think that lack of protection is=
 just easier to see.  Lack of cohesion
> requires trained eyes.

Precisely =
(that's what I meant by hard to quantify).

> I have to admit that every ti=
me I teach the
> 'Single Responsibility Principle' I feel a little odd.  It=
's not like
> you can use a check list which tells you whether you're viola=
ting it or
> not, you just have to show people enough examples for them to =
'get it.'

I stress the SRP pretty hard (both at method and class level), s=
ince  
it almost always pays off dramatically in terms of code  
reduction/=
reuse, system comprehension, and ease of maintenance, to  
name a few thing=
s. In contrast, I haven't seen "potential violation of  
encapsulation" cau=
se many real problems, at least not in the case of  
exposing attributes fo=
r test introspection.

> Justice Potter Stewart said (paraphrasing) "I
> ma=
y not be able to define obscenity, but I know it when I see it."

Which can=
 work well (but isn't sufficient for) characterizing design.  
And man, are=
 there lots of obscene designs out there!

Jeff
